text: (upbeat music)
- I am Taimur Rashid,

head of Generative AI
Innovation and Delivery at AWS.

Join me as I talk to leaders
and innovators across Amazon
who are using AWS generative AI

to create hyper-personalized
experiences for customers,
streamline operations,
improve productivity, and so much more.
Learn more inside GenAI at Amazon.
(upbeat music)
I'm really excited about today's session.
I'm being joined by Mari Joller.

Can you tell us a little
bit about yourself
and what you do at Amazon?
- Absolutely.

So I'm a senior manager
product at Amazon Music.
My team builds AI-powered products
for both music and podcasts.

For example, last April,
we launched Maestro,

which is our first foray
into GenAI at music.

And it is a AI-powered
playlist generation experience

where customer can input
the natural language prompt
and get a playlist in return.
And as an entrepreneur,

I've actually been using
AI for a long time.

My company, Snackable, joined
Amazon about two years ago.
I initially to work on podcasts,
so we all love listening to podcasts,
but as we know they can be long,

and it's sometimes hard to
understand what's inside.
So the Snackable technology now used AI
to essentially analyze the audio
and pull out those interesting segments,
or snacks as we call them,

to basically enable customers
to preview the podcasts

and then ascertain if they
wanted to listen for more.

And it's really been a
stepping stone for the work
that I do at Amazon today,
which expands podcasts and music
and also across voice and visual surfaces.
- No, that's great to see.
I'm a big fan of listening to music

and was really excited to see
the announcement of Maestro.

Can you tell us a little bit
about, you know, more broadly
how the use of generative AI
is helping to improve customer experience?
- Absolutely.

So in music, for example,
creating a playlist
used to be the purview of just a few.
You really had to be a music aficionado

or a radio DJ to build the
perfect mixtape for somebody.

And with generative AI,
we're democratizing that.

We're really bringing the
playlist generation experience
to the fingertips of many.
So anybody can really create a playlist.

For example, on my way
over to this interview,
I asked Maestro to inspire me
for an interview about generative AI.

And the resulting track
list was very fascinating.
It had some futuristic songs,

like David Bowie's "Space
Oddity", for example.

And so, you know, what we are
doing is really using Maestro

to bring this completely
new interaction paradigm

to customers, and it
opens up possibilities,
and it's been really rewarding

to see the reactions from
folks when they have this tool
at their disposal.
When we were launching Maestro,
we did some tests with Amazon employees,

and I remember somebody really
just yell, you know, saying,

"Wow, now I can make a playlist
for my family barbecue."
And the database backs it up as well.
So if we look at the proportion
of Maestro-generated playlists

as a percentage of overall,
you know, playlists
in our database,

we see this number
increasing quite quickly
and that really gives us the confidence

and satisfaction that we
are allowing customers

to really tap into the creativity
with this new technology.

- That's really exciting how
you can use natural language

to influence the kind of playlist
that you wanna listen to.
I also, on my way here,
I was just listening to music as well too.
So we both were doing the same thing.
Generative AI has this power
to really solve business problems.
And you know, when I talk to customers,

there's so many use cases
that they think about.

As you all were thinking about
the usage of generative AI,

how were you thinking about
it from the perspective
of what use cases to enable

or what specific business
problems to solve?
- Sure, that's a really great question.

And I would say that
GenAI is really changing

how customers expect to find
both information and content.

And in short, they
really expect to interact
with this technology using the full range
of human expression.
So at Amazon Music,
we also want customers to interact with us
the way they would speak to a friend.
And so the way that we're working

with the foundational
models underneath the hood
is really constructing those pieces
that help us, one, understand,
for example, the customer's intent
behind the prompt,
match the prompt to the content,
and then finally present that content

in a way that feels enriching
and dynamic to the customer.
So we weave that complexity

into a seamless natural
interaction paradigm
for the customer

without them ever seeing the
complexity underneath the hood.
And so in music, what it means that it's,

I can find and I can refine
what I wanna listen to.

So I could say to Maestro,
"Build me a rock roadtrip."

And so you would get a playlist
that has this fun title

and also an explanation as
to why we've recommended that
to you as a customer.
So it might say, you know,
"Hit the road with these rockers,
of the likes of U2, Nirvana, and others."

And in podcasts also
we can really reimagine
the discovery experience.
So say I was into meditation,

and I was listening to an
episode by "10% Happier"
and I thought to myself,
"Well, how could I find other content
that talks about meditation?"
And so I might see then this topic

that we've extracted using
GenAI that says meditation.
I click on it and now I land on a page

where I see old episodes
across our entire catalog

across different shows
that talk about meditation.
So what we've done is that we've created

this kind of horizontal
web of connectivity
between different pieces of content,
and it really transforms
how quickly and efficiently customers

can discover content that
really interest them.
- It's remarkable to see

how these generative AI
applications have a very seamless
and simple experience for the end user,
and it abstracts all that complexity.
Speaking of complexity,

could you tell us a little
bit about the AWS services
that you use to power the application

and what sort of drove the
selection of those services?
- Absolutely.

Amazon Bedrock has been
a key partner for us

as we've been on this innovation
journey with generative AI.

We've benefited from the
variety of foundation models
that Bedrock has to experiment,
but also to productionalize
and also to scale the customer experiences
both across music and podcasts.

And Bedrock has provided
us with the flexibility
we've needed on this innovation journey.
Especially as, you know,
this technology is evolving very rapidly,

whether that is new model
versions or capabilities or tools.

And we've also benefited
from associated capabilities
that are available on Bedrock.

And one to call out would be
trust and safety guardrails
to ensure that our customers

are able to safely interact
with these new services.
And also that the generated content
then safeguards our customers,

but also our artists and creative
partners and Amazon brand.
- You know, that's so important.
I'm glad you mentioned guardrails
because as, you know,

organizations build
these generative AI apps,
you know, sort of respecting
the data privacy, data security,
and ensuring that whatever's generated

is actually the right
content you want to give
to the end user so important.
- Absolutely.
- You know, I know it's still early days
for what you've all built with Maestro,
and you know, more capabilities
that you'll have in the future.

Are there sort of some
immediate benefits you've seen
and observed from your customers
as they've started interacting
with those generative AI solutions?
- Yes, absolutely.

The one that I am really
enthusiastic about

is that GenAI has really
allowed our customers
to be more creative in a new way

in how they interact
with music and podcasts.
And it's this type of behavior change

that's been really fun
to watch and to nudge

and also see customers nudge
the technology themselves.

So when the customers
first come into Maestro,
they would might do something very simple,
like say, Adele or '90s hip-hop,
but as they see examples
and I guess they get more comfortable,

they start also pushing on
the technology to get more.

So they might say things
like Sunset Cocktails

or something like mountain
crunchy granola vibes
and really lean into that technology.
And that's been really fantastic to watch

where people take this bolder
steps and get more creative.

Because we really want
people to get any music
or podcasts that really suits
their in-the-moment listening needs,
any whim, any mood, any activity.
And it really helps them

to get more out of our
vast catalog of content.

And the other thing
that's worth mentioning

is that the depth of personalization
that we're able to go
with GenAI is really unprecedented.

So we don't really tell you
anymore that you like rock
or U2 or Pink.

We tell you that you like
powerful female rockers
or U2 ballads or legendary guitar riffs.

And that's just a very
different level of familiarity

or personalization that we
can make them experience
much more magical for customers.
- You know, I have to agree with you.
Just being able to use a music-based app
with these features,
it not only drives more engagement,

I mean, I can even say
that on a personal level,
but you feel this sense of creativity

and ownership in the
music that you listen to
and so you can really personalize it.
So I'm glad you mentioned that
'cause that definitely is something
that I've experienced firsthand.

You and many other teams
at Amazon are trailblazing

and adding these GenAI
capabilities into applications.

As you've gone through
this early experience,
what are some key lessons
that you've learned throughout the journey
in adopting the technology
and then more importantly,

scaling it to, you
know, millions of users?
- Yeah, that's a really great question,

and it feels like we just
started using the technology
and it's been so many learnings,
and at the same time,

it feels like we're just
scratching the surface of this,
you know, massive wave that's yet to come.

And there's definitely
been many learnings.

I think, perhaps, three
are worth calling out
that are, perhaps, a bit more unique
of we didn't always expect to see.
But I would say in the first one
is the progress is not always linear.

The assumption is that
things will get better,

and they have, and they
have massively done so.
But sometimes we go backwards,
and then we have to tweak a bit.
So for examples,

we might see that the
next version of a model
introduces hallucination to our use case.
And then it's important for us
to always have this quality valuation data
and methods to ensure that we measure
and maintain the performance.

And the second one, I'd
say speed and quality.

So it's really great to
get a solution out of GenAI
that's 80% out-of-the-box magical.

And I think it's the
20% that's really hard
and that's what everybody is focusing on.

And so we are constantly
making the quality better,
and we're investing in that.
And so an example here

would be that we are seeing
a very popular track,
let's say, "Blinding Lights" by Weeknd
pop up on a variety of playlists.
And why is that?

It's because, in 2021, it
became the Billboard Hot 100
number one song in all of history.
And it's interesting because, you know,
when it comes to LLMs,
they are in essence a product
of what they've learned on the internet,
then their recommendations are, you know,
very much influenced by those learnings.

So that's something another
interesting learning for us.

And I would say the third
is trust and safety.
And so protecting our brand and customers
from potentially harmful or offensive
or biased content is crucial.
So robust trust and safety controls
continue to be our number one priority
as we move along in this space.

- Now, thank you for
sharing those lessons.

I think those are very
important for this audience
as they think about those lessons
and you know, kind of building
with those things in mind, right?
So accuracy of content,
but then more importantly, you know,
really understanding the impact

that wrong things can happen
on the brand itself, right.
So that's great.
Well, I'd like to, you know,

kind of close with a final
question about what's next.
You know, as you plan to expand
and enhance your use of generative AI
within the application,

how are you thinking
about that going forward?

- I would like to come
back with that question
to the beginning of our conversation,
which was about this great music expert
who is this some aficionado
and can make the perfect mixtape for you.
And that's really our vision

is to create this monocle
of music essentially,

which is the expert in your
pocket who truly knows you,
understands you,

gets you the right content
just when you need it.

And it's by combining this
great content with its history

and its cultural zeitgeist
into these foundational models

that will then enable to really
put that monocle of music
in your pocket.

And so in terms of how that
informs our plans forward,

I would say having the variety
of models available to us
and ways to explore will be key.

And so that we can get, for
example, the right size models
to do the right size tasks,

and then we can connect
them into this fun, dynamic,

and highly personalized
experience for our customers.
- That's really inspiring.
I really wanna thank you, Mari,
for the time that you spent with us,

the information you share,
and the insights as well, too.
So thank you.

- Thank you for having me.
It's a great discussion.
(bright music)
